content.raw: I will give a look at implementing the test cases for the branch ```xml_schema``` branch.
content.html: I will give a look at implementing the test cases for the branch xml_schema branch.

content.raw:
Pull-request #91 has some problems associated with auto-generation of xml schema files from SDF files. For example the following is considered valid the auto-generated schemas:

<link name="link">
    <inertial>       ...    </inertial>
    <inertial>       ...    </inertial>
</link>

An error should appear about multiple inertial values.

Once auto-generation is in place. I'll have to manually modify the XML schema files. At this point, we'll also switch over to using only the XML schema files. This will take a bit of work.
content.html:
Pull-request #91 has some problems associated with auto-generation of xml schema files from SDF files. For example the following is considered valid the auto-generated schemas:

<link name="link"> <inertial> ... </inertial> <inertial> ... </inertial> </link>

An error should appear about multiple inertial values.

Once auto-generation is in place. I'll have to manually modify the XML schema files. At this point, we'll also switch over to using only the XML schema files. This will take a bit of work.

content.raw: @nkoenig was the work in pull request #91 enough to close this issue?
content.html: @nkoenig was the work in pull request #91 enough to close this issue?

content.raw: Closing. I believe that we already implemented this.
content.html: Closing. I believe that we already implemented this.

content.raw: I'd like to make a few more changes. It's almost resolved.
content.html: I'd like to make a few more changes. It's almost resolved.

content.raw:
should we install the xml schemas?

cc @dirk-thomas

In order to reference them from .sdf file like this:

    <?xml-model href="url-to-xsd" schematypens="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"?>

they just need to be available via a fixed known URL.

It looks like http://sdformat.org/schemas/root.xsd or http://sdformat.org/schemas/world.xsd is the official location. Only http://sdformat.org/schemas/ doesn't list the files in this directory which made it more difficult for me to find them.
content.html:
In order to reference them from .sdf file like this:

<?xml-model href="url-to-xsd" schematypens="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"?>

they just need to be available via a fixed known URL.

It looks like http://sdformat.org/schemas/root.xsd or http://sdformat.org/schemas/world.xsd is the official location. Only http://sdformat.org/schemas/ doesn't list the files in this directory which made it more difficult for me to find them.

content.raw:
Hi, we are working on a Blender Robot designer Plugin in the Human Brain Project. We are currently adding support for SDF. We want to use pyxb to generate Bindings for the format out of the XSD files. There are, however, a couple of issues with the schema: Instead of the extensive use of <choice> one should rather use <all>. The example of inertia is still valid: inertial can have an infinite amount of inertia elements (and it can have an infinite amount of ixx). Using an autogenerated DOM this makes development rather tedious. Please take a look at this forum thread (https://sourceforge.net/p/pyxb/discussion/956708/thread/6c7fc2b0/).
Is there a way that we can contribute to the schema definition? We could also share our python parser with this project (blender and pyxb code is separated).
content.html: Hi, we are working on a Blender Robot designer Plugin in the Human Brain Project. We are currently adding support for SDF. We want to use pyxb to generate Bindings for the format out of the XSD files. There are, however, a couple of issues with the schema: Instead of the extensive use of <choice> one should rather use <all>. The example of inertia is still valid: inertial can have an infinite amount of inertia elements (and it can have an infinite amount of ixx). Using an autogenerated DOM this makes development rather tedious. Please take a look at this forum thread (https://sourceforge.net/p/pyxb/discussion/956708/thread/6c7fc2b0/). Is there a way that we can contribute to the schema definition? We could also share our python parser with this project (blender and pyxb code is separated).

content.raw:
`We could also share our python parser with this project (blender and pyxb code is separated). `

Depending on preferences, we can integrate the parser into this repository or you can 'define' it as an external project (creating a public repo could be enouh). In this later we can help into creating a debian/ubuntu package for it and submit it the official debian repositories.

` Is there a way that we can contribute to the schema definition?`

Probably @nkoenig can confirm that the schemas available at sdformat.org are generated using [an script](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/a3fa3d1163cc2fe991ac106e51695b99f8b119ca/tools/xmlschema.rb?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) from the SDF files. If this is the case, then patching the script could be the best option.

Thanks for the information!
content.html:
We could also share our python parser with this project (blender and pyxb code is separated).

Depending on preferences, we can integrate the parser into this repository or you can 'define' it as an external project (creating a public repo could be enouh). In this later we can help into creating a debian/ubuntu package for it and submit it the official debian repositories.

Is there a way that we can contribute to the schema definition?

Probably @nkoenig can confirm that the schemas available at sdformat.org are generated using an script from the SDF files. If this is the case, then patching the script could be the best option.

Thanks for the information!

content.raw:
So I started modifying the script. In many places it seems to be more suitable to use xsd:any instead of the automated way. In some places, it does not. I find the approach of describing the format in several files with a .sdf suffix rather strange in general. Imho it would have been better to define a XSD and use this for creating the DOM. 

Perhaps you could help me by clarifying some points. In the <model> element, is it possible to have <links> and <joints> in arbitrary order and numbers and <self_collide> only appear once? The specification does not state clearly any restrictions to the order.
Further, I do not think that it is possible to define this with XSD at all (in arbitrary order) – xsd:all does not allow for multiple elements of the same type and the combination of sequence/choice does not prevent multiple <self_collide> elements.
content.html:
So I started modifying the script. In many places it seems to be more suitable to use xsd:any instead of the automated way. In some places, it does not. I find the approach of describing the format in several files with a .sdf suffix rather strange in general. Imho it would have been better to define a XSD and use this for creating the DOM.

Perhaps you could help me by clarifying some points. In the <model> element, is it possible to have <links> and <joints> in arbitrary order and numbers and <self_collide> only appear once? The specification does not state clearly any restrictions to the order. Further, I do not think that it is possible to define this with XSD at all (in arbitrary order) – xsd:all does not allow for multiple elements of the same type and the combination of sequence/choice does not prevent multiple <self_collide> elements.

content.raw:
There are currently a few issues with the schema generation script

* Elements that have attributes as well as values (not child elements) are not handled properly. The only example so far is the `pose` element which has a `frame` attribute (soon to be changed to `relative_to`) and a value. The generated schema allows for the existence of the `frame` attribute but fails to validate for any given value.
* Certain elements appear in different contexts with different child elements and attributes. For example, the `<model>` tag is defined in `model.xsd` as well as `model_state.xsd`. Using `xsd:include` to include these xsd files causes a redeclaration error in the `xmllint` tool. eg. `Schemas parser error : Element '{http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}element': A global element declaration 'model' does already exist.`
* The schema validation tests use schemas downloaded from sdformat.org/schemas instead of locally generated ones. However, those schemas are not versioned and appear to be outdated. Is there reason not to use local files?
content.html:
There are currently a few issues with the schema generation script

  • Elements that have attributes as well as values (not child elements) are not handled properly. The only example so far is the pose element which has a frame attribute (soon to be changed to relative_to) and a value. The generated schema allows for the existence of the frame attribute but fails to validate for any given value.
  • Certain elements appear in different contexts with different child elements and attributes. For example, the <model> tag is defined in model.xsd as well as model_state.xsd. Using xsd:include to include these xsd files causes a redeclaration error in the xmllint tool. eg. Schemas parser error : Element '{http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}element': A global element declaration 'model' does already exist.
  • The schema validation tests use schemas downloaded from sdformat.org/schemas instead of locally generated ones. However, those schemas are not versioned and appear to be outdated. Is there reason not to use local files?
